Abstract
Nanoporosity of a shale gas reservoir provides essential information on the gas
accumulation space and controls the gas reserves. The characteristics of heterogeneous nanoporosity of four shale samples are analyzed by combining quantitative evaluation of minerals by scanning electronic microscopy (QEMSCAN), focused ion beam-scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM), and nano-CT. The representative elementary area (REA) is proposed by QEMSCAN to detect the imaging area that can represent the overall contents of minerals and organic matter. Combined with the statistics of pores in minerals and organic matter by FIB-SEM, the quantitative nanoporosity is obtained. The nano-CT is used to compare the total nanoporosity that was obtained by FIB-SEM. The results show that shale

has distinct characteristics in nanoporosities due to the variation in organic matter and mineral content. The major pore sizes of the organic matter and clay minerals are smaller than 400 nanometers (nm), and the pore sizes of feldspar and pyrite are mainly 200-600 nm. The pore sizes for pores developed in quartz and carbonate minerals range from a few nanometers to 1000 nm. Furthermore, pores smaller than 400 nm mainly provide the total nanoporosity. The nanoporosities in the organic matter are approximately 17%-21%. Since the organic matter content (0.54%-6.98%) is low, the organic matter contributes approximately 5%-33% of the total nanoporosity in shale. Conversely, the nanoporosities in quartz and clay are generally lower than 3%. Since the mineral content (93.02%-99.46%) is obviously higher than the organic matter content, the minerals contribute approximately 67%-95% of the total nanoporosity in shale.
Keywords
Nanoporosity; Organic pore; Mineral pore; Pore size distribution; Shale gas reservoir.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, the proportion of shale oil and gas has increased significantly in fossil
fuels, and shale formations account for approximately 32% of the total natural gas resources in the world (Bruijnincx and Weckhuysen, 2013; Mohr et al., 2015). Shale gas, a clean fuel compared to coal and oil, has attracted the attention of governments around the world (Chu and Majumdar, 2012; Chang et al., 2015). Shale pores, the direct storage space for shale oil and gas, have been the focus of previous studies, and knowledge of the pore spaces in tight shale has been progressed (Ross and Bustin, 2009; Clarkson et al., 2013; Tiwari et al., 2013;
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
Tang et al., 2015). Nanoporosity dominated by abundant nano-scale pores is the main difference between a shale reservoir and a conventional sand reservoir, especially organic nano-scale pores, which primarily develop in shale (Javadpour et al., 2007; Nelson, 2009).
At present, the approach to characterize shale nano-scale pores has gradually moved
from qualitative to quantitative (Loucks et al., 2009; Curtis et al., 2010). The main method of the qualitative studies is observation by a scanning electron microscope (SEM), which can be used to observe the shape, size, and spatial distribution of pores (Tian et al., 2013; Klaver et al., 2015). The pores under SEM can be divided into interparticle pores and intraparticle pores, and the organic pores are intraparticle pores within organic matter (Loucks et al., 2012). The main methods of the quantitative studies are mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP), gas adsorption, and computed tomography (CT), which can be used to determine the pore size distribution (Liu et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2016). Through the above methods, the understanding of shale nanoporosity has increased significantly (Nia et al., 2016; Wilson et al., 2016).
However, there are still two key scientific problems that remain unsolved. The first
problem is how to avoid the shale heterogeneity effect during the nanoporosity measurement. Shale usually has strong heterogeneity at the micro/nano scale (Yang et al., 2014; Kelly et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016). Removing the heterogeneity affects and obtaining the representative characteristics of shale with specific properties has yet to be solved. At a small field of view in SEM, the observed pores cannot represent the whole sample. At a large field of view in SEM, the property of the nano-scale pores cannot be determined. Choosing the proper field of view to prevent the influence of heterogeneity and clearly and accurately characterize the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
nano-scale pores is important. The second unresolved problem is how to scientifically obtain quantitative characteristics of the pores in and between organic matter (OM) and minerals in shale. Organic pores and mineral pores can be observed by SEM, but their quantitative characteristics cannot be effectively determined (Wang et al., 2014; Liu et al., 2015). The quantitative pore size distribution can be obtained by mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) and gas adsorption, but these techniques do not determine the contribution of each mineral and OM to the total nanoporosity (Clarkson et al., 2012; Labani et al., 2013).
In this paper, the contents of OM and different minerals are obtained through a
quantitative evaluation of the minerals using scanning electronic microscopy (QEMSCAN), and the nanoporosity in the OM and minerals are obtained by focused ion beam-scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM) and the ImageJ software. Then, the contribution of OM and minerals to the shale’s total nanoporosity is determined. Combined with the nanoporosity from the nano-CT, the differences of the nanoporosity distribution and the causes between the two methods are determined.

sections.heading: 2.1. Samples
sections.text:
Shale samples were collected from the Silurian Longmaxi Formation in the Sichuan
Basin, China. The Silurian Longmaxi Formation is mainly composed of organic-rich black shale (Tang et al., 2016). The wells are located in the Jiaoshiba shale gas block, which is the largest shale gas field in China (Fig. 1). First, we observed an approximately 100 m core of the whole Silurian Longmaxi Formation from the JY-1 well and YC-4 well. Based on the

observations, 40 samples were selected for thin section analysis. Then, according to the characteristics of the shale mineralogy and texture from the observations of the thin sections, four representative samples were collected from the JY-1 well and YC-4 well. Sample SG-1 is dark grey siliceous shale with few graptolites. Sample SG-2 is grey siliceous shale. Sample SG-3 is black shale with many graptolites. Sample SG-4 is light grey shale with many rastrites (Fig. 1c). These four samples were investigated using QEMSCAN, FIB-SEM, and nano-CT.

sections.heading: 2.2. QEMSCAN
sections.text:
Quantitative evaluation of minerals using a scanning electronic microscopy (QEMSCAN)
can generate images of the OM and minerals by scanning the sample (Tang et al., 2014). The instrument can provide the element information on each measurement point according to the X-ray energy spectrum. Based on the gray value of the back-scattered electron image and the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
6
intensity of the X-ray, the mineral phase can be determined. A QEMSCAN 650F instrument was used to analyze the OM and minerals of the samples at the China University of Petroleum, Beijing. The pixel resolution of the images is 1 µm. Because the shale mineral grain size is generally between 3.2 and 35 µm (Lei et al., 2015), an accurate determination of the content of the OM and minerals can be made by QEMSCAN.
Based on the spatial distribution of the OM and minerals, the representative elementary
area (REA) is proposed to detect whether the content of the OM and minerals represents the entire sample at a specific field of view (Klaver et al., 2015). The detection method is based on the assumption that the entire QEMSCAN image is divided into 20 images from the image center to the image edge, with the side length gradually increasing to 100 µm for each image (Fig. 2a). The dimensions of the smallest image are 100 × 100 µm2 (Fig. 2b). The OM and mineral contents were measured in each image. If the OM and minerals in the images gradually approached the overall composition and did not significantly change along the length increase from 100 µm to 2000 µm, it can be considered that the OM and minerals have self-similarity and that the content of the OM and minerals represent the whole sample. The area of the field of view of the smallest image with the OM and minerals similar to the overall composition is the representative elementary area (REA).

sections.heading: 2.3. FIB-SEM
sections.text:
FIB-SEM is widely used to characterize shale nano-scale pores (Gu et al., 2015). The
images used in this study were obtained using a FIB-SEM HELIOS 650 instrument at China University of Petroleum, Beijing. The smallest pixel resolution is approximately 1 nm. The image collection assumption is based on the idea that each type of mineral (quartz, feldspar, carbonate, clay, and pyrite) and OM for each sample is selected randomly, and the field of view is filled by a single mineral or OM (Fig. 3a). At least ten images were taken for each
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
8
type of mineral and OM for each sample.
The sizes of the mineral grains are generally between 3.2 and 35 µm (Lei et al., 2015),
and the corresponding mineral pixel resolution in the SEM images is approximately 1.6-17.5 nm, as the images have 2048 pixels in the horizontal direction. Thus, the mineral meets the requirements of nano-scale pore analysis. The pores of each mineral and OM were identified using the Image software J. At the single OM or mineral field of view, the OM or mineral surface morphology is clear and the pores are relatively easy to identify (Fig. 3). As the pore gray value is lower than the OM and mineral gray values, the pores can be extracted from the OM and mineral using the segmentation of the gray value. The pores can be divided into intragranular pores and intergranular pores. Since the OM and minerals share intergranular pores with adjacent minerals, only half the numbers of intergranular pores are measured. Then, the nanoporosities and pore size distribution of each mineral type and the OM is determined using the abundance of the intragranular pores and intergranular pores. Combining the content of the OM and minerals of the shale samples obtained by the QEMSCAN images, the total nanoporosities and pore size distribution of the shale sample can be determined.

sections.heading: 3.2. Representative elementary area (REA)
sections.text:
Shale heterogeneity is extremely strong at the micro/nano scale (Fig. 4b, d, f, h). In a
larger field of view than used previously, the heterogeneity becomes weaker, the OM and minerals start to exhibit self-similarity (Fig. 4a, c, e, g), and the mineral content varies less (Fig. 5). Shale with low quartz content has a smaller REA than that with high quartz content (Fig. 5). For example, sample SG-1 has the highest quartz content and its REA is 1.4 × 1.4 mm2, but sample SG-4 has the lowest quartz content and a REA of 0.6 × 0.6 mm2. The REAs of the four samples are generally smaller those that of Bakken Formation shale, Haynesville shale, and Posidonia shale, which are generally between 0.14 × 0.14 mm2 to 0.6 × 0.6 mm2 (Klaver et al., 2012; Klaver et al., 2015; Saraji and Piri, 2015). The strong heterogeneity and unstable mineralogy abundances lead the statistical error from a single image to be smaller than the REA. In this study, the field of view of the QEMCAN image is larger than the REA. Therefore, the content of the OM and minerals obtained by QEMSCAN can represent the overall sample properties.

The total nanoporosity of shale can be calculated by combining the nanoporosities of the
OM and minerals and the abundances of the OM and minerals (Equation 1). The nanoporosity changes with the composition of the OM and minerals (Fig. 8). Although the nanoporosity in quartz is low in sample SG-1, quartz has a very high abundance at 91.56%, so quartz provides the majority of the nanoporosity in the sample and the contribution of other minerals and OM is limited (Fig. 8a). For the sample SG-2, in addition to the high contribution of quartz to the total nanoporosity, the OM also contributes a high proportion of the total nanoporosity, with pore diameters below 100 nm (Fig. 8b). For sample SG-3, the OM is the largest contributor to the total nanoporosity, especially for pores with diameters below 100 nm, which contributes more than half of the total nanoporosity (Fig. 8c). For sample SG-4, the clay minerals are the major contributor to the nanoporosity of the sample, mostly by pores with diameters below 300 nm (Fig. 8d).

The spatial distribution of the shale pores was obtained through nano-CT (Fig. 9).
According to the pore size, volume, and amount, the nanoporosity distribution can be determined (Fig. 10). The nanoporosity from the nano-CT is a volume percentage of the pore space shown in the 3D images. Because the pixel resolution of the nano-CT is 65 nm, pores smaller than 65 nm in diameter cannot be resolved. At the pore range of 65 to 1000 nm, the nanoporosity is mainly from pores that are smaller than 400 nm (Fig. 10). The incremental nano-CT nanoporosity generally decreases with the increase in pore diameter. The total nano-CT nanoporosities are between approximately 1.6% and 2.4%.

As FIB-SEM and nano-CT can both determine connected pores, isolated pores, and
throats, they should have a similar pore size distribution. From Fig. 8 and Fig. 10, the FIB-SEM nanoporosity and nano-CT nanoporosity are both from pores that are smaller than 400 nm in diameter. They have similar pore size distributions, which indicate that the nanoporosity obtained by the FIB-SEM is correct. However, the total nanoporosity generated from the FIB-SEM is higher than the total nanoporosity rendered from the nano-CT. Because the pixel resolution of the nano-CT is 65 nm, pores smaller than 65 nm in diameter cannot be resolved. Furthermore, pores smaller than 65 nm in diameter are a larger percentage of the shale pores, according to the results of the FIB-SEM nanoporosity (Fig. 8). Since the nano-CT

samples are too small and exhibit heterogeneity, the total nanoporosity from the nano-CT does not correlate to the real nanoporosity (Kelly et al., 2015). In addition, the resolution size of the nano-CT samples is only 65 µm, and the samples are heterogeneous at this scale because the REA is between 0.6 x 0.6 mm2 and 1.4 x 1.4 mm2 (Fig. 5). Therefore, the nanoporosity from the nano-CT is lower than the nanoporosity from the FIB-SEM, and their pore size distributions are not consistent. 4.2. Pore size distribution of OM and minerals
Organic pores have been the focus of a number of recent studies throughout the world.
The pore size distribution of OM pores is affected by maturity, TOC content, mineral composition, stress, and so on (Curtis et al., 2012; Hao et al., 2013). Milliken et al. indicated that the organic pores in high TOC shales are smaller than those in low TOC shales using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (Milliken et al., 2013). Guo et al. determined that the organic pores in the early mature shale of the Yanchang Formation are smaller than 200 nm and that very few pores are larger than 200 nm based on Nano-CT image analysis (Guo et al., 2105). Wang et al. concluded that the organic pores in over-mature shales of the Jiulaodong Formation are commonly 500-1100 nm through 3D nano-TXM analysis (Wang et al., 2016). However, Chen et al. showed that the organic pores in the over-mature shales of the Niutitang Formation are smaller than 150 nm through FE-SEM observation (Chen et al., 2016). Furthermore, there are many viewpoints for the organic pores of the Silurian Longmaxi Formation shale. For example, Zhou et al. determined that the organic pores are commonly 5-200 nm in diameter through FIB-SEM observation (Zhou et al., 2016). Jiao et al. showed that the organic pores are 4-483 nm in diameter through FIB-SEM

observation (Jiao et al., 2014). In addition, Yang et al. concluded that the organic pores are between 4 and 350 nm in diameter through FE-SEM observation (Yang et al., 2016). In this study, the organic pores range from 1 nm to 1000 nm in diameter, using FIB-SEM. Based on the elimination of shale heterogeneity, the organic pores in the Longmaxi Formation shale are smaller than 400 nm, and the percentage of pores decreases as the pore size increases (Fig. 11f).
There are few studies regarding mineral pores in shale. Most of the studies focus on the
overall inorganic pores, but the pores in each type of mineral have yet to be studied in detail. Due to the various maturities, TOC content, and minerals, inorganic pores vary in pore size distribution. Houben et al. studied clay layer pores in the shaly facies of Mont Terri, Switzerland, and found that the clay layer pores are 40-1000 nm in diameter through BIB-SEM observation (Houben et al., 2014). Moreover, Klaver et al. studied the clay-rich matrix pores in the Haynesville and Bossier Shales and found the shales are mainly clay-rich matrix pores with sizes between 30 nm and 300 nm in diameter through BIB-SEM observation (Klaver et al., 2016). Chen et al. indicated that the inorganic pores in the over-mature shale of the Niutitang Formation are mainly 100-600 nm in diameter under FE-SEM observation (Chen et al., 2016). Wang et al. concluded that the inorganic pores in the over-mature shale of the Jiulaodong Formation are mainly 10-1000 nm in diameter under FIB-SEM observation (Wang et al., 2016). Jiao et al. determined that the inorganic pores in the Longmaxi Formation shale are commonly between 31 and 1976 nm in diameter through FIB-SEM observation (Jiao et al., 2014). In this study, the pore size distribution of each type of mineral and OM vary from 1 nm to 1000 nm by FIB-SEM. The clay mineral pores are

primarily smaller than 400 nm, similar to organic pores (Fig. 11d). The feldspar pores and pyrite pores are between 200 and 600 nm in diameter (Fig. 11b and e). The quartz pores and carbonate pores range from a few nanometers to 1000 nm, and the pores smaller than 300 nm comprise a high percentage of the total pores (Fig. 11a and c).
The characteristics of the pores are controlled by their own properties. Organic pores are
well developed in high thermal maturity (Ro), and organic pores increase as the thermal maturity increases (Klaver et al., 2016). The thermal maturity of the Longmaxi Formation shale is generally higher than 2% (Tang et al., 2015), which is better for generating more organic pores (Fig. 12a and b). The sizes of the clay minerals are generally smaller than those of other minerals, and clay minerals are easily deformed (Lei et al., 2015), which makes them easier to form small strip pores (Fig. 12c and d). The porosity in quartz, feldspar, and carbonate are controlled by their own primary porosity development and later diagenesis (Houben et al., 2014), which may form dissolution pores (Fig. 13a, b and c). Pyrite pores are mainly controlled by the size and arrangement of pyrite crystals (Fig. 13d).

sections.heading: 4.3. Contribution of OM and minerals to total nanoporosity
sections.text:
Organic pores are important for shale gas, and there have been a number of studies on
organic pores, which has led the contribution of mineral pores to be ignored. The macropores and mesopores provided by clay and carbonate, for example, are important for shale reservoirs under FE-SEM and TEM observation (Chalmers et al., 2012). Klaver et al. concluded that there are very few organic pores, which are more developed in over-mature shales through BIB-SEM observation (Klaver et al., 2012; Klaver et al., 2016). On the other hand, Guo et al. showed that the content of organic pores is two times higher than inorganic pores in the early shale of the Yanchang Formation based on Nano-CT image analysis (Guo et al., 2015). Furthermore, Löhr et al. indicated that organic pores are present in early mature and over-mature shales, but not in oil-mature shales, because organic pores are filled with bitumen (Löhr et al., 2015). For over-mature shale, Wang et al. determined that OM provided approximately 35% of the total nanoporosity in the over-mature shale of the Niutitang Formation under FIB-SEM observation (Wang et al., 2016), while organic pores contributed the majority proportion of the pores in the over-mature shale of the Lomgaxi Formation and the nanoporosity in OM is approximately 29.88% (Shi et al., 2015; Zhou et al., 2016). Tian et al. stated that the percentages of organic matter pores range between 31% and 62% for the Longmaxi shale, with TOC values of 1%-4% based on the relationship between total porosity and TOC content of 8 samples (Tian et al., 2015). Jiao et al. proposed that organic pores were
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
23
the most abundant pore type in the Longmaxi shale through FIB-SEM observation (Jiao et al., 2014).
The contribution of organic pores in shale to the total nanoporosity can be easily
exaggerated because of the effects of heterogeneity and the OM content (Yang et al. 2016). Although organic pores are well developed in OM, when the OM content is low, the contribution of organic pores to the total nanoporosity will still be relatively low (such as sample SG-1, Fig. 8a). The nanoporosities in OM and minerals and the content of OM and minerals are both important to the total nanoporosity. When the mineral content is high, minerals still contribute significantly to the total nanoporosity, although the nanoporosities in the minerals are generally low, such as in sample SG-1. In this sample, although the nanoporosity in quartz is very low (Fig. 7), the quartz content is high (91.56%). The high quartz content allows quartz to be the largest contributor to the total nanoporosity. Therefore, in heterogeneous Longmaxi Formation shale, organic pores and mineral pores both contribute to the total nanoporosity and the content of the minerals and OM affect the total nanoporosity (Fig. 8). For good shale gas reservoirs (samples SG-2 and SG-3), OM appears to play a more important role in the total nanoporosity because the OM content is generally high (Fig. 8).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The pore size distribution of OM and minerals is mainly controlled by their own
attributes. Organic pores and clay mineral pores have similar pore size distributions, with pore sizes smaller than 400 nm. Pores in feldspar and pyrite are between 200 and 600 nm in diameter. Pores in quartz and carbonate vary from a few nanometers to 1000 nm, and pores

Nanoporosity in OM is approximately 17%-21%, which is clearly higher than that of
other minerals. Nanoporosity in minerals is generally low, especially for quartz and clay, which have nanoporosities lower than 3%. The total nanoporosity is controlled by the nanoporosities of the OM and minerals and the abundance of the OM and minerals in shale. The total nanoporosity is primarily from pores smaller than 400 nm in diameter. Furthermore, organic pores play an important role when the OM content is high in shale gas reservoirs, but the contribution of inorganic pores cannot be ignored.

metadata.abstractText: Nanoporosity of a shale gas reservoir provides essential information on the gas accumulation space and controls the gas reserves. The characteristics of heterogeneous nanoporosity of four shale samples are analyzed by combining quantitative evaluation of minerals by scanning electronic microscopy (QEMSCAN), focused ion beam-scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM), and nano-CT. The representative elementary area (REA) is proposed by QEMSCAN to detect the imaging area that can represent the overall contents of minerals and organic matter. Combined with the statistics of pores in minerals and organic matter by FIB-SEM, the quantitative nanoporosity is obtained. The nano-CT is used to compare the total nanoporosity that was obtained by FIB-SEM. The results show that shale M AN US CR IP T AC CE PT ED ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2 has distinct characteristics in nanoporosities due to the variation in organic matter and mineral content. The major pore sizes of the organic matter and clay minerals are smaller than 400 nanometers (nm), and the pore sizes of feldspar and pyrite are mainly 200-600 nm. The pore sizes for pores developed in quartz and carbonate minerals range from a few nanometers to 1000 nm. Furthermore, pores smaller than 400 nm mainly provide the total nanoporosity. The nanoporosities in the organic matter are approximately 17%-21%. Since the organic matter content (0.54%-6.98%) is low, the organic matter contributes approximately 5%-33% of the total nanoporosity in shale. Conversely, the nanoporosities in quartz and clay are generally lower than 3%. Since the mineral content (93.02%-99.46%) is obviously higher than the organic matter content, the minerals contribute approximately 67%-95% of the total nanoporosity in shale.
